concept.title: ActionCard
concept.shortdesc: An action card results in a transaction, an attestation or a component of a transaction.

conbody.p: Action card is a type of card that triggers an action in the wallet or dapp browser. They allow a dApp to interact with the most important features of the wallet: The usage of keys. But they are not restricted to this.

Action Cards can be triggered by the user, for example by touching a button in the wallet. But they can also be triggered by websites or dApps through JavaScript. They either appear as a pop up in the browser or directly in your wallet.

Action Cards never happens on a website or any third party host. Those can just trigger it. Action cards separate operations and websites. In many cases Action Cards can replace a minimalist website, for example when such a website just helps users to do a simple transaction to a smart contract.

If you are a token issuer, you probably already have a Dapp website that helps your users to do transactions with your token. With Action Cards the user will be able to do the same in their own wallet or on other website that uses your token (not owned by you).
As one example, if you have deposited a token to a DEFI project and want to redeem (or "withdraw") it, this can be done by clicking a button which triggers an action card.

Action Cards can trigger onchain operations like transactions. But they also allow a token creator to enable offchain operations: The user can sign a message, start a process to attest his email address, send an authorise to let someone else to use your token (if the underlying token's smart contract accepts such authorisations) or create a deal to share (requires underlying contract's support).

Some action cards can only be available in a specific context, like "Show entrance Pass" is an action only available at a gate of a stadium, or "Prolong rental" is only avaiable if you have a car-rental (not your own car).

It is possible to use two action cards at the same time or in combination. This is called a deck. One successful Action Card can enable another, or the combination of two action cards can unlock a new operation.
